title: Functionality of Oxide based devices under Electric-field: Towards Atomic-resolution Operando Nanoscopy

Abstract:

Title: Functionality of Oxide based devices under Electric-field: Towards Atomic-resolution Operando Nanoscopy (FOXON)

The FOXON project aims to revolutionize our understanding of oxide electronics by advancing our ability to observe and correlate the dynamic electrical behavior of metal-insulator-metal (MIM) structured devices with their atomic structures in real-time. Our objective is to bridge the gap between theoretical models and experimental realities by employing cutting-edge operando nanoscopy techniques.

We propose to develop a novel microelectromechanical systems (MEMS)-based chip that facilitates in situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis while simultaneously performing electrical biasing of electron-transparent lamella devices. This lab-on-a-chip approach enables us to observe the atomic-level mechanisms of oxide electronics under direct electric fields, focusing on the switching phenomena of oxide thin films and interfaces.

Our scientific mission involves comprehensive studies on the dynamics of oxygen vacancies and the stability of quantized conductance states in resistive random-access memory (RRAM) devices. We anticipate that the FOXON platform will allow us to perform concurrent current-voltage measurements with structural, chemical, and electronic analyses, shedding light on the atomic-level processes that govern device behavior.

The proposed project is built upon previous work (Ultramicroscopy 181 (2017) 144-149; Adv. Funct. Mater. (2017) 1700432) and seeks to develop beyond state-of-the-art techniques for operando TEM of MIM devices. Through this project, we expect to pave the way for new advancements in nanoelectronics and quantum information technologies by providing a deeper understanding of oxygen dynamics in emergent oxide electronics.

The potential impact of FOXON is significant, offering the possibility of translating nanoscale insights into macroscopic device performance improvements, thereby contributing to the advancement of next-generation electronic materials and devices.

Abstract:

The "Functionality of Oxide based devices under Electric-field: Towards Atomic-resolution Operando Nanoscopy" (FOXON) project represents a pioneering investigation into the atomic-scale mechanisms that govern the performance of metal-insulator-metal (MIM) structured devices in oxide electronics. FOXON's central objective is to bridge the existing gap between theoretical models and experimental observations by correlating electrical behavior with atomic structure during device operation. This entails operando investigations of oxide thin films and interface switching phenomena under electrical bias, thus providing insights into the dynamics of oxygen vacancies and the stability of quantized conductance states in resistive random-access memory (RRAM) devices.

Employing cutting-edge techniques such as the use of microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) chips for in situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and advanced lab-on-a-chip approaches, FOXON will enable current-voltage measurements concomitant with structural, chemical, or electronic structure analysis. Building upon prior foundational studies published in "Ultramicroscopy" and "Advanced Functional Materials," the project will develop a novel MEMS-based chip designed for in situ electrical biasing, facilitating the electrical contact and operation of an electron-transparent lamella device.

The FOXON initiative aspires to significantly advance the field of nanoelectronics by realizing beyond state-of-the-art operando TEM capabilities for MIM structured devices. This breakthrough will foster a comprehensive understanding of atomic-level mechanisms in oxide electronics, which is essential for the development of new quantum and information technologies. The project's success will not only answer open questions in the realm of oxide electronics but also pave the way for the creation of superior device performance driven by a deep understanding of oxygen dynamics.

Abstract:

Title: Functionality of Oxide based devices under Electric-field: Towards Atomic-resolution Operando Nanoscopy (FOXON)

The FOXON project seeks to fundamentally enhance the understanding of oxygen dynamics in oxide electronics, a field that is pivotal to the advancement of emergent quantum and information technologies. Aimed at bridging the gap between theoretical models and experimental reality, the project will focus on atomic scale operando investigations of oxide thin film and interface switching phenomena in metal-insulator-metal (MIM) structured devices under electrical bias. The proposed research endeavors to correlate electrical behavior and atomic structure during device operation, while simultaneously performing current-voltage measurements and analyzing structural, chemical, or electronic changes.

Utilizing innovative techniques such as microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) chips for in situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and a lab-on-a-chip approach, the project will develop a novel MEMS-based chip for in situ electrical biasing. These advancements will allow the team to conduct unprecedented studies on the dynamics of oxygen vacancies and the stability of quantized conductance states in resistive random-access memory (RRAM) devices, as highlighted in Ultramicroscopy and Advanced Functional Materials.

The expected outcomes of FOXON include the establishment of a new platform for operando TEM of MIM structured devices, providing insights into atomic-level mechanisms in oxide electronics. Such knowledge is essential for the design of superior oxide electronic devices with enhanced performance and reliability. Ultimately, the project aims to pave the way for novel quantum and information technologies by advancing the understanding of tunable physical properties in oxide-based nanoelectronics.

Keywords: oxide electronics, operando nanoscopy, MEMS chips, in situ TEM, electrical biasing, MIM devices, oxygen vacancies, RRAM, quantum technologies.

Abstract:

Title: Functionality of Oxide based devices under Electric-field: Towards Atomic-resolution Operando Nanoscopy (FOXON)

The FOXON project seeks to revolutionize the understanding of oxide electronics through state-of-the-art experimental techniques that bridge the gap between current theoretical models and experimental reality. The central objective is to elucidate the interplay between the electrical behavior and atomic structure of metal-insulator-metal (MIM) structured devices under electric fields, with a focus on oxygen dynamics and interface switching phenomena. The expected outcome is to inform the design of advanced nanoelectronics and foster the development of new quantum and information technologies.

To achieve these aims, the project proposes the development of novel microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) chips for operando transmission electron microscopy (TEM) studies. These chips will facilitate in situ electrical biasing of electron-transparent lamella devices, thus enabling simultaneous current-voltage measurements and structural, chemical, or electronic structure analysis during device operation. The lab-on-a-chip approach will allow controlled studies of metal-oxide functional devices, furthering understanding of the atomic-level mechanisms that govern their properties.

This project builds on prior work, including the successful electrical contact and operation of a lamella device fabricated from a MIM structure, and the design of a MEMS-based chip for in situ electrical biasing, as documented in "Ultramicroscopy" and "Advanced Functional Materials," respectively. These studies have laid the groundwork for a deeper investigation into the dynamics of oxygen vacancies and the stability of quantized conductance states in resistive random-access memory (RRAM) devices.

Through FOXON, we anticipate significant advancements in the operando TEM field, ultimately paving the way for novel device architectures and functionalities in oxide electronics. The project stands to make a substantial impact on the scientific community's understanding of oxide-based devices, with broad implications for the future of technology.
